content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: Find a course on Coursera named 'Introduction to Mathematical Thinking' offered by Stanford, what is the percentage (rounded) of 5 star ratings in reviews and which level has the least percentage?.  Please interact with https://www.coursera.org/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to search for the course; clicking the Search icon should reveal the search textbox.  
Action: Click [301]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search textbox is open and focused; I should type the course name to search.  
Action: Type [2333]; Introduction to Mathematical Thinking
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to open the course page to view rating details.  
Action: Click [3600]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to locate the ratings breakdown section — likely farther down the page — to get % of 5‑star ratings, plus the learner‑reported “level” breakdown (Beginner / Intermediate / Advanced).  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to scroll further down the page to reach the ratings‑breakdown and learner‑level graphs.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: We still haven't reached the ratings & learner‑feedback section; keep scrolling further down.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Still no “Reviews” section; need to continue scrolling downward to reach the learners’ ratings breakdown.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I’ve scrolled near the very bottom (Explore more…). The Learner‑reviews section must be above; I should scroll back upward to locate it—likely right after the Instructor or Syllabus sections, or via “Reviews” tab near top.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The page’s internal navigation list shows a “Reviews” link that should jump to the ratings section where the 5‑star percentage and learner‑level breakdown reside.  
Action: Click [5485]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: We have the star‑rating percentages (5‑star = 84.18%), but need the learner‑level breakdown (Beginner / Intermediate / Advanced). That data is likely further below in the Reviews section.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “View more reviews” link likely opens the full reviews page that provides extra breakdowns such as learner‑level percentages.  
Action: Click [7741]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to find the learner‑level (Beginner / Intermediate / Advanced) percentage breakdown – likely farther down this reviews/feedback page.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “All Learners” filter dropdown should reveal learner‑level categories with their percentage shares.  
Action: Click [9448]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The learner‑level filter dropdown might be just above current viewport; scrolling slightly down may bring it fully into view so it can be interacted with.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To see the learner‑level breakdown percentages, open the “All Learners” dropdown.  
Action: Click [9448]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to locate the learner‑level percentages (Beginner / Intermediate / Advanced). They’re usually shown above the reviews list near the rating summary graph, so I should scroll upward above the “1 – 25 of 729 Reviews …” heading.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to reach the rating‑summary section near the very top of the Reviews page (where the Beginner/Intermediate/Advanced bars appear).  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Return to the main course page where the ratings breakdown (84 % five‑star) was visible and where the learner‑level distribution (Beginner / Intermediate / Advanced) usually appears, then capture which level has the smallest share.  
Action: GoBack
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: 5‑star rating % is visible (84.18%). Need learner‑level breakdown (Beginner / Intermediate / Advanced), likely a bit further below in the same Reviews area—scroll down to locate it.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The learner‑level percentages aren’t below; they’re likely above the star‑rating block. I should scroll up to check directly above the ratings summary for a “Beginner / Intermediate / Advanced” bar chart.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need learner‑level breakdown; the “View more reviews” link opens detailed reviews page that includes filter with level percentages.  
Action: Click [14409]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “View more reviews” link still fails to execute, possibly due to context. Another path: the “About” section often contains the learner‑level breakdown (Beginner / Intermediate / Advanced). I should open the About tab.  
Action: Click [12174]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “Beginner / Intermediate / Advanced” learner‑level breakdown should be near the star‑rating block; scrolling a little upward from current position may reveal it.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Jump to the Reviews section (same page) where star‑rating breakdown appears; there, a learner‑level distribution (Beginner / Intermediate / Advanced) should also be shown.  
Action: Click [12186]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need the “Reviews” anchor link to navigate to the ratings section; first make sure the navigation bar is firmly in view, then try clicking the “Reviews” link again.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I’m at the “About” section (#about). The course page has in‑page navigation tabs (About, Reviews, etc.) located just above; need to reach them and click “Reviews” to access the ratings breakdown, then read learner‑level percentages.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need the sticky section‑navigation bar (with link “Reviews”) which appears after scrolling a bit; then I can click “Reviews” to jump to ratings breakdown that includes learner‑level percentages.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down

Observation: please analyze the accessibility tree and give the Thought and Action.

Thought: Need to reach the Reviews section farther below to obtain star‑rating percentage and learner‑level breakdown; continue scrolling downward through the page until that section appears.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
